p: In addition to cell wall chitin and glucans, the surface of C. albicans is decorated with proteins called adhesins that play a pivotal role in cell communication, adhesion and microbial infection [ 72, 73]. Many adhesins are mannoproteins that are homogenously dispersed on the cell surface [ 74, 75]. Cell wall stress, temperature variation, exposure to antifungal agents, host interaction and biofilm formation have been shown to alter the adhesive properties of cells [ 67, 76]. Adhesive forces in this study are based on the interaction between the cell surface and the hydrophilic, negatively charged silicon nitride AFM tip. Exposure to CNB oil gave rise to a moderate increase in cell adhesion, which may be attributed to cell wall remodelling, as evidenced by concomitant changes in roughness. Changes in adhesion may reflect loss or rearrangement of adhesins, or reorganization of surface sugars [ 25, 27, 29].
